I looked, and unless I'm retarded, I can't seem to find a qtddtot thread, and I'm new to this hobby, so I had some questions of my own to ask (in the replies). Feel free to ask your own questions, hopefully this thread can be a small resource for newbies like me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Paper Recommendations? I've been using Neenah Exact Index 110 lbs cardstock, and had a good bit of luck. I know that the sticky provides some answers on this, but I've noticed a pretty obvious and wide variety of paper weights and finishes, and I'm pretty sure some posters are even using some kind of origami paper for their models, so I wanted to hear your thoughts on this.
Glue application tips? Been using a toothpick to carefully apply Elmer's Glue to my models, but I always feel like I'm using too much or too little, and I've been having a really hard time not getting glue all over the outside of my more detailed models, perhaps it just requires patience and skill, but any advice would be appreciated.
Thanks in advance /po/bros

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Since I like to draw my models instead of printing them, I have one more question:
Is there a resource out there for basic shapes? I can figure most things out, but I'd love to figure out how to do spheres and domes efficiently; how do you all do it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>608493
>>608494

110lbs is a little thick for my taste, I have a stack of 86lbs and I find that suits my needs, but it depends on the model that you're building. Don't be afraid to experiment with different weights.
I use a sewing needle to apply glue to my models. It definitely takes practice to get a nice neat application so just keep at it.
Hand drawn templates can provide more freedom in template design compared to the traditional 3d>pep workflow. I don't hand draw my designs, but conveying the shape of curves and spheres without using 3d will take some experimentation, but will probably yield better results than using 3d geometry.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>608493
Freehand spheres are gonna look like tomatillo.
Use high school geometry and traditional manual drafting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>608499
Sorry it took so long for me to get back to you, I've since started two more paper craft projects, and I've really been enjoying the hobby!
I've played around with paper and thought a lot about which works best, and I've since realized just how much it depends on what you're going to do with it. Lately I've been testing odd pieces of paper to test how well each one holds, folds, and rolls. Some paper can hold itself almost entirely upright under its own weight, while other paper seems to provide almost perfect creases. All in all, I do still think it fits into personal preference and experience, and I've been sticking with my 110 because it's what I use at work.
Thank you for the advice.

posts.com:
>>577761

>>609071
>o noes it happened once and the artist panicked!
This happens again and again and again. They eventually speak up about these crimes and get /po/opered for it. After enough of it they make their papercraft fun again by going totally private, no longer dealing the nasty diseased public on the internet.
Everything costs, profit is needed to keep a website up, pay for internet service, software licenses, stuff to make the test builds from, time spent by the designer, their years of experience they worked to learn and experiment.
Notice the difference in quality between free papercraft and pirated papercraft?
Did website maintenance for a papercrafter years and years ago. He had a few free items, some pay items, and a few large complex items reserved for premium buyers. He was earning enough to keep the site up, and sometimes a few shitty dollars profit.
/po/ found the website, sales dropped so badly that he was in the red for an entire year. Posts a new item... one purchase, gets posted here, no more sales. /po/opers figured out how to access the premium items (buy 5 or more items using one account). They got posted here, no more sales.
For months he was literally paying to give items away, /po/'s actions forced him to close the site.
He's a friend, still makes papercraft, always improving and becoming more creative. None of which will ever be seen because of /po/'s bigotry, he won't even let me take photos.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>609077
TL;DR: It's the internet, privacy is going to happen whenever possible, and it's important to adapt to it. On /po/ you can download a car, remember that.

I can understand your argument to an extent, but on the other hand, there are really obvious ways of safeguarding one's own finances as an artist in this craft.
Limited high-quality print runs provide fans a way to own physical copies of artwork which will retain their value; a coffee table book featuring designs, photos, and artist commentary is one such example of this practice.
An artist could also open up an online storefront specializing in supplies, kits, completed works, and/or commissioned works. In this way, a hobby can be a tax-deductible at worst, and a profit generator at best, with minimal costs involved and minimal need to worry about piracy.
Let's not forget the ever-reliable social media/Patreon combo either. Using free platforms to host content, while giving fans an easy way to provide financial support is a bullet-proof strategy when it comes to monetizing a hobby, and it's why pretty much every artist on the internet does it. In this specific case, it doesn't matter as much if the art gets shared around, it's free marketing as long as the artist puts their handle somewhere on the design.
People, especially artists and academics, forget that the internet's main purpose is to allow as many people to share as much information as possible. Failure to adapt to that as an artist is not the internet's fault. Much like how it would be absurd for an artist to blame his knife over a misplaced cut. Even in a perfect world, where people somehow managed to make papercraft piracy completely impossible, other people would simply make free versions of the design, or go the hand-drawn route (like I do).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Recently it was the 100th anniversary of Shuzo Fujimoto's birthday. He was the father of tessellation folds. You probably are familiar with his hydrangea model. Fujimoto wrote 8 books, of which the first five have been out of print. In honor of his 100th anniversary, his estate has released these books into the public domain. You can download them at the link.
https://cfcorigami.com/creator/shuzofujimoto

These are not "diagram books." They are more like his notebooks for his many models. You may need a translation program, like Google Lens, to figure out what he's writing about. Have at it.

I need to buy a new printer and it must be an inkjet. Iâve shopped around but I canât make a decision on which one to get. Right now Iâm looking seriously at the Epson EcoTank line of printers just because I tend to print a ton of stuff for my projects and the tank makes it easy to refill.

posts.name: Will
posts.com: I have a Brother MFC-j4410dw wide format printer (11x17)... It'll handle 110# cardstock, and ink is fairly cheap... You can find them on ebay for well under your limit... When my 7 year old one finaly started wearing out, I got a nearly new one for just under $100 on ebay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I took the plunge and purchased a Canon Pixma G6020. Honestly it's one of the best purchases I have made. I've had it for months and the tanks are only about halfway empty. The quality is great, though this is from experience with only old HP Photosmart printers that I kept running well past their date. The only thing I wish it could do is wide format prints so I could more easily make my own posters.

posts.name: Ezikialrage
posts.com:
>>601036
I recommend and HP printer that has an instant ink subscription if you like to do lots of papercraft projects. Its a subscription service based on the number of pages you want to print a month and HP will send you high yield ink cartridges. You if you run out of ink before you use what ever page limit is HP will send you more cartridges for free.So its good for people who like to print books, paper craft,school worksheets and photos. They have 10 page, 50 page, 100 page, 300 page and 700 page a month subscription services. Which ranges from a dollar for the 10 pages a month to 25 dollars for the 700 page a month subscription service.
